awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Flexible biodegradable medical device tether and inserter
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop an understanding of the market needs for a novel biodegradable tether and inserter technology. Researchers have developed an inserter device which delivers a temporary tether into living tissue that can constrain medical devices within the body, while also permitting those devices to be easily removed if desired. Numerous surgical and implant applications might benefit from commercialization of this technology, and the market needs for these applications will be explored in this project.  A potential application of the technology is with postpartum intrauterine devices (IUD) where this will mitigate medical complications caused by IUD expulsion events.

This I-Corps project focuses on a novel technology for inserting a biodegradable tether into living tissue and interfacing with existing medical devices.  This technology must permit the medical devices to be held in place during normal operation, but allow easy removal when desired.  Researchers have fabricated alpha and beta prototypes that demonstrate reliable insertion of a biodegradable tether into explanted muscle tissue and shown sufficient anchoring force to constrain a medical device.  Using the same tether, researchers have demonstrated easy removal of a medical device.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this I-Corps project was to establish the product-market fit of a flexible biodegradable tether technology developed in the Medical Device Lab at UT-Austin. We hypothesized that our technology could help reduce unplanned pregnancy by interfacing with commercially available intrauterine devices (IUDs), and therefore be of interest to mothers, clinicians, and insurance companies.

During the team's participation in the NSF I-Corps program, many crucial aspects of the potential product-market fit in the United States were brought to light over the course of the team's 111 total customer interviews. The major customer segments interviewed included recently pregnant and currently pregnant women, OB/GYN clinicians, policy experts, public and private reimbursement organizations, medical device and IUD manufacturers/distributors, and hospital procurement and billing experts.

The I-Corps program provided all participants an overview of entrepreneurship training.

The results from I-Corps include one conference proceeding and one patent application (pending): 

1. C. Idelson, A. Jayarajan, M.Y. Williams-Brown, C. Rylander (2018). "Novel Intrauterine Technology to Mitigate Postpartum Intrauterine Device Expulsion," World Congress of Biomechanics, 2018.

2. SYSTEMS AND METHODS TO DECREASE INTRAUTERINE DEVICE EXPULSION AND PERFORATION. Patent No. PCT/US2018/0183 UNITED STATES. Application Pending.

This project provided education to all members of the team, both project specific technology-market fit, and general entrapreneurship education.

This project provided information about market opportunities that were communicatated to the UT- Office of Technology Commercialization which is continuing to license the technology to existing companies.

This technology may have the ability to reduce unplanned preganancy which has potential impact to millions of people globally.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2022
Modified by: Christopher G Rylander
